SOME RESULTS ON THE BROWNIAN MEANDER WITH DRIFT

F. Iafrate and E. Orsingher Sapienza, University of Rome, Italy. enzo.orsingher@uniroma1.it, francesco.iafrate@uniroma1.it
Abstract.

In this paper we study the drifted Brownian meander, that is a Brownian motion starting from u𝑢u and subject to the condition that min0≤z≤t⁡B​(z)>vsubscript0𝑧𝑡𝐵𝑧𝑣\min_{0\leq z\leq t}B(z)>v with u>v𝑢𝑣u>v. The limiting process for u↓v↓𝑢𝑣u\downarrow v is analyzed and the sufficient conditions for its construction are given. We also study the distribution of the maximum of the meander with drift and the related first-passage times. The representation of the meander endowed with a drift is provided and extends the well-known result of the driftless case. The last part concerns the drifted excursion process the distribution of which coincides with the driftless case.

Key words and phrases:
Keywords: Tightness, Weak convergence, First passage times, Absorbing drifted Brownian motion, Drifted Brownian Excursion

1. Introduction

The Brownian meander is a Brownian motion {B​(t),t>0}𝐵𝑡𝑡0\{B(t)\,,\,\,t>0\} evolving under the condition that min0≤s≤t⁡B​(s)>0subscript0𝑠𝑡𝐵𝑠0\min_{0\leq s\leq t}B(s)>0. If the additional condition that B​(t)=c>0𝐵𝑡𝑐0B(t)=c>0 then we have the Brownian excursion which is the bridge of the Brownian meander.

Early results in this field emerged in the study of the behaviour of random walks conditioned to stay positive where the Brownian meander was obtained as the weak limit of such conditional processes ([2], [12]). In the same spirit the distribution of the maximum of the Brownian meander and excursion has been derived in [15]. Further investigations about such distributions can be found in [7]. Some important results can also be found in the classical book by Itô and McKean [13]. The notion of Brownian meander as a conditional Brownian motion and problems concerning weak convergence to such processes have been treated in [11]. More recently analogous results have been obtained in the general setting of Lévy processes (see for example [6]).

Brownian meanders emerge in path decompositions of the Brownian motion. In particular Denisov ([8]) shows that a Brownian motion around a maximum point can be represented (in law) by means of a two-sided Brownian meander, which is constructed by gluing together two meanders.

These processes also arise in several scientific fields. Possible applications range from SPDE’s with reflection ([4]) to enumeration of random graphs (see [14] for a survey of the results in this field).

In this paper we study the meandering process of the drifted Brownian motion Bμ​(t)superscript𝐵𝜇𝑡B^{\mu}(t) and, in particular we start by analyzing the joint n−limit-from𝑛n-fold distributions

P​{⋂j=1n(Bμ​(sj)∈d​yj)|min0≤z≤t⁡Bμ​(z)>v,Bμ​(0)=u}𝑃conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛superscript𝐵𝜇subscript𝑠𝑗dsubscript𝑦𝑗formulae-sequencesubscript0𝑧𝑡superscript𝐵𝜇𝑧𝑣superscript𝐵𝜇0𝑢P\bigg{\{}\bigcap_{j=1}^{n}\left(B^{\mu}(s_{j})\in\mathrm{d}y_{j}\right)\,\Big{|}\min_{0\leq z\leq t}B^{\mu}(z)>v,B^{\mu}(0)=u\bigg{\}} (1.1)

In order to examine the interesting case where the starting point coincides with the barrier level v𝑣v we use the tools of weak convergence of probability measures. In section 2 we briefly recall the needed results and in section 3 we show that the required conditions hold.

2. Preliminaries

Let {B​(t),t∈[0,T]}𝐵𝑡𝑡0𝑇\{B(t),t\in[0,T]\} be a Brownian motion adapted to the natural filtration on some measurable space (Ω,ℱ)Ωℱ(\Omega,\mathscr{F}) and let {Pu,u∈ℝ}subscript𝑃𝑢𝑢ℝ\{P_{u},u\in\mathbb{R}\} be a family of probability measures such that, under each Pusubscript𝑃𝑢P_{u}, B𝐵B is a Brownian motion and P​(B​(0)=u)=1𝑃𝐵0𝑢1P(B(0)=u)=1. We consider a drifted Brownian motion {Bμ​(t),0≤t≤T}superscript𝐵𝜇𝑡0𝑡𝑇\{B^{\mu}(t),0\leq t\leq T\} defined as Bμ​(t)=B​(t)+μ​t,0≤t≤Tformulae-sequencesuperscript𝐵𝜇𝑡𝐵𝑡𝜇𝑡0𝑡𝑇B^{\mu}(t)=B(t)+\mu t\,,0\leq t\leq T, with μ∈ℝ𝜇ℝ\mu\in\mathbbm{R}. The space C​[0,T]𝐶0𝑇C[0,T] of its sample paths, sometimes indicated as ω=ω​(t)𝜔𝜔𝑡\omega=\omega(t), is endowed with the Borel σ𝜎\sigma-algebra 𝒞𝒞\mathscr{C} generated by the open sets induced by the supremum metric.

For a given probability space (Ω,ℱ,P)Ωℱ𝑃(\Omega,\mathscr{F},P) we define the random function

Y:(Ω,ℱ)↦(C​[0,T],𝒞).:𝑌maps-toΩℱ𝐶0𝑇𝒞Y:(\Omega,\mathscr{F})\mapsto(C[0,T],\mathscr{C})\,\,. (2.1)

We take a probability measure μ𝜇\mu on (C​[0,T],𝒞)𝐶0𝑇𝒞(C[0,T],\mathscr{C}) defined as

μ​(A)=P​(Y−1​(A))A∈𝒞.formulae-sequence𝜇𝐴𝑃superscript𝑌1𝐴𝐴𝒞\mu(A)=P(Y^{-1}(A))\qquad A\in\mathscr{C}\,\,. (2.2)

For a set Λ∈𝒞Λ𝒞\Lambda\in\mathscr{C} such that μ​(Λ)>0𝜇Λ0\mu(\Lambda)>0 we consider the space (Λ,𝒞,μ(⋅|Λ))(\Lambda,\mathscr{C},\mu(\,\cdot\,|\Lambda)) which is the trace of (C​[0,T],𝒞,μ)𝐶0𝑇𝒞𝜇(C[0,T],\mathscr{C},\mu) on the set ΛΛ\Lambda, where the conditional probability measure μ(⋅|Λ):Λ∩𝒞↦[0,1]\mu(\,\cdot\,|\Lambda):\Lambda\cap\mathscr{C}\mapsto[0,1] is defined in the usual sense as

μ​(A|Λ)=μ​(A∩Λ)μ​(Λ)A∈𝒞.formulae-sequence𝜇conditional𝐴Λ𝜇𝐴Λ𝜇Λ𝐴𝒞\mu(A|\Lambda)=\frac{\mu(A\cap\Lambda)}{\mu(\Lambda)}\qquad A\in\mathscr{C}\,\,. (2.3)

We then construct the space (Y−1(Λ),ℱ∩Y−1(Λ),P(⋅|Y−1(Λ)))\big{(}Y^{-1}(\Lambda),\mathscr{F}\cap Y^{-1}(\Lambda),P(\,\cdot\,|Y^{-1}(\Lambda))\big{)} where

P​(A|Y−1​(Λ))=P​(A∩Y−1​(Λ))P​(Y−1​(Λ)) for ​A∈ℱ∩Y−1​(Λ).formulae-sequence𝑃conditional𝐴superscript𝑌1Λ𝑃𝐴superscript𝑌1Λ𝑃superscript𝑌1Λ for 𝐴ℱsuperscript𝑌1ΛP(A|Y^{-1}(\Lambda))=\frac{P(A\cap Y^{-1}(\Lambda))}{P(Y^{-1}(\Lambda))}\qquad\text{ for }A\in\mathscr{F}\cap Y^{-1}(\Lambda)\,\,. (2.4)
Definition 2.1.

Given a random function Y𝑌Y as in (2.1) and a set Λ∈𝒞Λ𝒞\Lambda\in\mathscr{C} the conditional process Y|Λconditional𝑌ΛY|\Lambda is defined as the restriction of Y𝑌Y to the set ΛΛ\Lambda:

Y|Λ:(Y−1(Λ),ℱ∩Y−1(Λ),P(⋅|Y−1(Λ)))↦(Λ,𝒞,μ(⋅|Λ))Y|\Lambda:\big{(}\,Y^{-1}(\Lambda),\mathscr{F}\cap Y^{-1}(\Lambda),P(\,\cdot\,|{Y^{-1}(\Lambda)})\,\big{)}\mapsto(\Lambda,\mathscr{C},\mu(\,\cdot\,|\Lambda))\,\, (2.5)

The following lemma provides the conditions for a conditional process to be Markov (see [11]).

Lemma 2.1.

Let Y𝑌Y be a Markov process on C​[0,T]𝐶0𝑇C[0,T] and let Λ∈𝒞Λ𝒞\Lambda\in\mathscr{C} such that μ​(Λ)>0𝜇Λ0\mu(\Lambda)>0. Let π[0,t]subscript𝜋0𝑡\pi_{[0,t]} and π[t,1]subscript𝜋𝑡1\pi_{[t,1]} be the projection maps on C​[0,T]𝐶0𝑇C[0,T] onto C​[0,t]𝐶0𝑡C[0,t] and C​[t,1]𝐶𝑡1C[t,1], respectively. If for all t∈[0,T]𝑡0𝑇t\in[0,T] there exist sets At∈ℬ​(C​[0,t])subscript𝐴𝑡ℬ𝐶0𝑡A_{t}\in\mathscr{B}(C[0,t]) and Bt∈ℬ​(C​[t,1])subscript𝐵𝑡ℬ𝐶𝑡1B_{t}\in\mathscr{B}(C[t,1]) such that Λ=π[0,t]−1​At∩π[t,1]−1​BtΛsuperscriptsubscript𝜋0𝑡1subscript𝐴𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡11subscript𝐵𝑡\Lambda=\pi_{[0,t]}^{-1}A_{t}\cap\pi_{[t,1]}^{-1}B_{t} then Y|Λconditional𝑌ΛY|\Lambda is Markov, where ℬℬ\mathscr{B} denotes the Borel sigma-algebra.

In the following μ​(⋅)𝜇⋅\mu(\,\cdot\,) denotes the Wiener measure on (C​[0,T],𝒞)𝐶0𝑇𝒞(C[0,T],\mathscr{C}). For a Brownian motion starting at u𝑢u we usually write P(⋅|B(0)=u)P(\,\cdot\,|B(0)=u) to denote Pu​(⋅)subscript𝑃𝑢⋅P_{u}(\,\cdot\,) to underline the dependence on the starting point. The drifted Brownian meander can be represented as a conditional process Bμ|Λu,vconditionalsuperscript𝐵𝜇subscriptΛ𝑢𝑣B^{\mu}|\Lambda_{u,v} where the conditioning event Λu,vsubscriptΛ𝑢𝑣\Lambda_{u,v} is of the form

Λu,v={min0≤z≤t⁡Bμ​(z)>v,Bμ​(0)=u}.subscriptΛ𝑢𝑣formulae-sequencesubscript0𝑧𝑡superscript𝐵𝜇𝑧𝑣superscript𝐵𝜇0𝑢\Lambda_{u,v}=\Big{\{}\min_{0\leq z\leq t}B^{\mu}(z)>v,B^{\mu}(0)=u\Big{\}}\,.

Analogously the Brownian excursion is a conditional process Bμ|Λu,v,cconditionalsuperscript𝐵𝜇subscriptΛ𝑢𝑣𝑐B^{\mu}|\Lambda_{u,v,c} with

Λu,v,c={min0≤z≤t⁡Bμ​(z)>v,Bμ​(0)=u,Bμ​(t)=c}u,c>v.formulae-sequencesubscriptΛ𝑢𝑣𝑐formulae-sequencesubscript0𝑧𝑡superscript𝐵𝜇𝑧𝑣formulae-sequencesuperscript𝐵𝜇0𝑢superscript𝐵𝜇𝑡𝑐𝑢𝑐𝑣\Lambda_{u,v,c}=\Big{\{}\min_{0\leq z\leq t}B^{\mu}(z)>v,\,B^{\mu}(0)=u,B^{\mu}(t)=c\Big{\}}\qquad u,c>v\,\,.

We remark that the conditional processes introduced above are Markovian in light of Lemma 2.1.

For some fixed v>0𝑣0v>0, we need to study the weak convergence of the measures μu,v:=μ(⋅|Λu,v)\mu_{u,v}:=\mu(\,\cdot\,|\Lambda_{u,v}) as u↓v↓𝑢𝑣u\downarrow v. See Billingsley [3] for a treatise of the general theory of weak convergence. We here recall the main concepts we will make use of.

Definition 2.2.

Given a metric space (S,ρ)𝑆𝜌(S,\rho) and a family ΠΠ\Pi of probability measures on (S,ℬ​(S))𝑆ℬ𝑆(S,\mathscr{B}(S)), ℬ​(S)ℬ𝑆\mathscr{B}(S) being the Borel σ−limit-from𝜎\sigma-field on S𝑆S, we say that ΠΠ\Pi is tight if

∀η>0∃ compact ​K⊂Ss.t.∀μ∈Πμ​(K)>1−η.formulae-sequencefor-all𝜂0formulae-sequence compact 𝐾𝑆s.t.formulae-sequencefor-all𝜇Π𝜇𝐾1𝜂\forall\eta>0\quad\exists\text{ compact }K\subset S\quad\text{s.t.}\quad\forall\mu\in\Pi\quad\mu(K)>1-\eta.

The tightness property is equivalent to relative compactness if (S,ρ)𝑆𝜌(S,\rho) is separable and complete, as estabilished in a well-known theorem due to Prohorov, and it is thus relevant to prove the weak convergence of measures. In fact the following theorem holds (see [3], Theorem 7.1, or [16], Theorem 4.15).

Theorem 2.1.

Let {X(n)}nsubscriptsuperscript𝑋𝑛𝑛\{X^{(n)}\}_{n} and X𝑋X be stochastic processes on some probability space (Ω,ℱ,P)Ωℱ𝑃(\Omega,\mathscr{F},P) onto (C​([0,T]),𝒞)𝐶0𝑇𝒞(C([0,T]),\mathscr{C}) and let {μn}nsubscriptsubscript𝜇𝑛𝑛\{\mu_{n}\}_{n} and μ𝜇\mu, respectively, the induced measures. If for every m𝑚m and for every 0≤t1<t2<⋯​tm≤t0subscript𝑡1subscript𝑡2⋯subscript𝑡𝑚𝑡0\leq t_{1}<t_{2}<\cdots t_{m}\leq t, the finite dimensional distributions of (Xt1(n),…,Xtm(n))subscriptsuperscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝑡1…subscriptsuperscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝑡𝑚(X^{(n)}_{t_{1}},\ldots,X^{(n)}_{t_{m}}) converge to those of (Xt1,…,Xtm)subscript𝑋subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑋subscript𝑡𝑚(X_{t_{1}},\ldots,X_{t_{m}}) and the family {μn}subscript𝜇𝑛\{\mu_{n}\} is tight then μn⇒μ⇒subscript𝜇𝑛𝜇\mu_{n}\Rightarrow\mu.

In the following section we will compute the limit of the finite dimensional distributions. As far as the tightness is concerned we will make use of the following theorem ([3], Theorem 7.3) which characterizes the tightness of a family of measures induced by a process with a.s. continuous paths in terms of its modulus of continuity mωT​(δ)=sups,t∈[0,T]:|t−s|<δ|ω​(s)−ω​(t)|superscriptsubscript𝑚𝜔𝑇𝛿subscriptsupremum:𝑠𝑡0𝑇𝑡𝑠𝛿𝜔𝑠𝜔𝑡m_{\omega}^{T}(\delta)=\sup_{s,t\in[0,T]:|t-s|<\delta}|\omega(s)-\omega(t)|.

A sequence of probability measures {Pn}nsubscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛𝑛\{P_{n}\}_{n} on (C​[0,T],𝒞)𝐶0𝑇𝒞(C[0,T],\mathscr{C}) is tight if and only if

    ∀η>0​∃afor-all𝜂0𝑎\qquad\forall\eta>0\,\,\exists a and N𝑁N such that Pn(ω:|ω(0)|>a)<η,∀n≥N,\displaystyle P_{n}(\omega:|\omega(0)|>a)<\eta,\,\,\forall n\geq N, and

    ∀η>0limδ↓0lim supn→∞Pn​{ω:mωT​(δ)≥η}=0.formulae-sequencefor-all𝜂0subscript↓𝛿0subscriptlimit-supremum→𝑛subscript𝑃𝑛conditional-set𝜔superscriptsubscript𝑚𝜔𝑇𝛿𝜂0\qquad\displaystyle\forall\eta>0\quad\lim_{\delta\downarrow 0}\limsup_{n\to\infty}P_{n}\{\omega:m_{\omega}^{T}(\delta)\geq\eta\}=0.

Condition (i​i)𝑖𝑖(ii) is difficult to prove directly so we use the Kolmogorov-Centšov theorem which necessitates bounds on the expectation of the increments. We first recall the Kolmogorov-Čentsov theorem ([16], Th. 2.8).

Theorem 2.3.

Suppose that a process X={X​(t),0≤t≤T}𝑋𝑋𝑡0𝑡𝑇X=\{X(t),0\leq t\leq T\} on a probability space (Ω,ℱ,P)Ωℱ𝑃(\Omega,\mathscr{F},P) satisfies the condition

P​{ω:sups,t∈[0,T]|t−s|<h​(w)|X~​(ω,t)−X~​(ω,s)||t−s|γ≤δ}=1𝑃conditional-set𝜔subscriptsupremum𝑠𝑡0𝑇𝑡𝑠ℎ𝑤~𝑋𝜔𝑡~𝑋𝜔𝑠superscript𝑡𝑠𝛾𝛿1P\left\{\omega:\sup_{\begin{subarray}{c}s,t\in[0,T]\\ |t-s|<h(w)\end{subarray}}\frac{|\tilde{X}(\omega,t)-\tilde{X}(\omega,s)|}{|t-s|^{\gamma}}\leq\delta\right\}=1 (2.7)

The Kolmogorov-Čentsov theorem can be exploited to prove the tightness property of a family of measures as stated in the following result ([16], Problem 4.11)

It is easily seen that conditions (i)i(\emph{i}) and (ii)ii(\emph{ii}) of Proposition 2.1 imply the corresponding conditions of Theorem 2.2.

Returning to our main task, once proved that the collection of measures {μu,v}u>vsubscriptsubscript𝜇𝑢𝑣𝑢𝑣\{\mu_{u,v}\}_{u>v} satisfies the conditions of Theorem 2.1 and Theorem 2.2, by exploiting Proposition 2.1, we are able to assess the existence of some process whose finite dimensional distributions coincide with those of the weak limit μvsubscript𝜇𝑣\mu_{v} of μu,vsubscript𝜇𝑢𝑣\mu_{u,v} when u↓v↓𝑢𝑣u\downarrow v. Λv={ω:inf0<z<Tω​(z)>v,ω​(0)=v}.subscriptΛ𝑣conditional-set𝜔formulae-sequencesubscriptinfimum0𝑧𝑇𝜔𝑧𝑣𝜔0𝑣\Lambda_{v}=\Big{\{}\omega:\inf_{0<z<T}\omega(z)>v,\omega(0)=v\Big{\}}.

This means that the continuous mapping theorem holds, i.e. μu,v∘g−1subscript𝜇𝑢𝑣superscript𝑔1\mu_{u,v}\circ g^{-1} ⇒u→v→𝑢𝑣⇒\xRightarrow{u\to v} μv∘g−1subscript𝜇𝑣superscript𝑔1\mu_{v}\circ g^{-1} for any bounded uniformly continuous g𝑔g. Using this fact we can derive the distribution of the maximum of max⁡Bμ|Λvconditionalsuperscript𝐵𝜇subscriptΛ𝑣\max B^{\mu}|\Lambda_{v} as the weak limit of max⁡Bμ|Λu,vconditionalsuperscript𝐵𝜇subscriptΛ𝑢𝑣\max B^{\mu}|\Lambda_{u,v}. This was done in the driftless case by Durrett and Iglehart [10].

3. Weak convergence to the Brownian meander with drift

The drifted Brownian meander can be viewed as a Brownian motion Bμsuperscript𝐵𝜇B^{\mu} with drift restricted on the subsets of continuous functions Λu,v={ω∈C​[0,T]:min0≤z≤T⁡ω​(z)>v,Bμ​(0)=u}subscriptΛ𝑢𝑣conditional-set𝜔𝐶0𝑇formulae-sequencesubscript0𝑧𝑇𝜔𝑧𝑣superscript𝐵𝜇0𝑢\Lambda_{u,v}=\{\omega\in C[0,T]:\min_{0\leq z\leq T}\omega(z)>v,B^{\mu}(0)=u\}, with u>v𝑢𝑣u>v. The probability measure we consider here is applied to the events A={⋂j=1n{Bμ​(sj)∈d​yj}}𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛superscript𝐵𝜇subscript𝑠𝑗dsubscript𝑦𝑗A=\big{\{}\bigcap_{j=1}^{n}\{B^{\mu}(s_{j})\in\mathrm{d}y_{j}\}\big{\}} under the condition {min0≤z≤T⁡Bμ​(z)>v,Bμ​(0)=u}formulae-sequencesubscript0𝑧𝑇superscript𝐵𝜇𝑧𝑣superscript𝐵𝜇0𝑢\{\min_{0\leq z\leq T}B^{\mu}(z)>v,B^{\mu}(0)=u\}. Remark 3.1.

This result shows that, as a consequence of the Kolmogorov-Čentsov theorem, the drifted Brownian meander, i.e. the weak limit of the sequence {Bμ|Λu,v,u>v}conditional-setsuperscript𝐵𝜇subscriptΛ𝑢𝑣𝑢𝑣\{B^{\mu}|\Lambda_{u,v},u>v\}, is a.s. locally Hölder continuous of parameter γ∈(0,1/2)𝛾012\gamma\in(0,1/2). The Brownian meander thus inherits the same Hölder exponent as the underlying unconditional Brownian motion, as could be expected.

We are now able to prove the tightness of the family of measures induced by the drifted Brownian meander.

Theorem 3.2.

The family of measures {μu,v}usubscriptsubscript𝜇𝑢𝑣𝑢\{\mu_{u,v}\}_{u} on (C​[0,T],𝒞)𝐶0𝑇𝒞(C[0,T],\mathscr{C}) indexed by u𝑢u, given by

is tight.

Proof.

The result follows as an application of Proposition 2.1. The proof that the sequence of measures {μu,v}u>vsubscriptsubscript𝜇𝑢𝑣𝑢𝑣\{\mu_{u,v}\}_{u>v} satisfies condition (i​i)𝑖𝑖(ii) is given in Lemma 3.1. Condition (i)𝑖(i) clearly holds since P​(Bμ​(0)=u)=1𝑃superscript𝐵𝜇0𝑢1P(B^{\mu}(0)=u)=1 for u>v𝑢𝑣u>v.

∎

Lemma 3.2.

Theorem 3.3.

The following weak limit holds:

Bμ|{min0≤z≤t⁡Bμ>v,Bμ​(0)=u}⇒u↓vBμ|{inf0<z<tBμ>v,Bμ​(0)=v}↓𝑢𝑣absent⇒conditionalsuperscript𝐵𝜇formulae-sequencesubscript0𝑧𝑡superscript𝐵𝜇𝑣superscript𝐵𝜇0𝑢conditionalsuperscript𝐵𝜇formulae-sequencesubscriptinfimum0𝑧𝑡superscript𝐵𝜇𝑣superscript𝐵𝜇0𝑣B^{\mu}\Big{|}\Big{\{}\min_{0\leq z\leq t}B^{\mu}>v,B^{\mu}(0)=u\Big{\}}\xRightarrow[u\downarrow v]{}B^{\mu}\Big{|}\Big{\{}\inf_{0<z<t}B^{\mu}>v,B^{\mu}(0)=v\Big{\}} (3.9)
Proof.

In view of Lemma 3.2 and Theorem 3.2, result (3.9) is an application of Theorem 2.1. ∎

We now check that the maximum variation around the starting point for the drifted meander tends to zero, in a sense which is made precise in the following corollary.

The last expression corresponds to the univariate distribution of the drifted Brownian meander, whose density is given in (3.8). ∎

Remark 3.2.

Either from the last expression of (3.8) or directly from the first one we get

P​{Bμ​(t)∈d​y|inf0<z<tBμ​(z)>v,Bμ​(0)=v}𝑃conditional-setsuperscript𝐵𝜇𝑡d𝑦formulae-sequencesubscriptinfimum0𝑧𝑡superscript𝐵𝜇𝑧𝑣superscript𝐵𝜇0𝑣\displaystyle P\bigg{\{}B^{\mu}(t)\in\mathrm{d}y\bigg{|}\inf_{0<z<t}B^{\mu}(z)>v,B^{\mu}(0)=v\bigg{\}}

4. About the maximum of the Brownian meander

In this section we study the distribution of the maximum of the drifted Brownian meander and then we use the results about the maximum to derive the distribution of the first passage time.

  2. (ii)

    For x→∞→𝑥x\to\infty, μ≠0𝜇0\mu\neq 0, we obtain that (4.6) tends to 1 as can be seen from (4.4).

    In order to prove that (4.6) for x→0→𝑥0x\to 0, μ≠0𝜇0\mu\neq 0 we write

    ∑k=−∞+∞(−1)k​e−x2​k22​t+μ​k​x=∑k=−∞+∞(−1)k​e−x2​k22​t​(1+∫0μ​k​xew​dw).superscriptsubscript𝑘superscript1𝑘superscript𝑒superscript𝑥2superscript𝑘22𝑡𝜇𝑘𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑘superscript1𝑘superscript𝑒superscript𝑥2superscript𝑘22𝑡1superscriptsubscript0𝜇𝑘𝑥superscript𝑒𝑤differential-d𝑤\sum_{k=-\infty}^{+\infty}(-1)^{k}e^{-\frac{x^{2}k^{2}}{2t}+\mu kx}=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{+\infty}(-1)^{k}e^{-\frac{x^{2}k^{2}}{2t}}\left(1+\int_{0}^{\mu kx}e^{w}\,\mathrm{d}w\right).

    (see [9], eq. (3.4.9)).

    Note that for μ=0𝜇0\mu=0 we have that (4.7) coincides with the distribution of the maximum of the Brownian bridge, that is

|B​(T0+s​(t−T0))|t−T0=i.d.M​(s)0<s<1\frac{\Big{|}B(T_{0}+s(t-T_{0}))\Big{|}}{\sqrt{t-T_{0}}}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle i.d.}}{{=}}M(s)\qquad 0<s<1 (5.1)

Remark 5.1.

For μ=0𝜇0\mu=0 result (5.2) coincides with (5.1), valid for the non-drifted Brownian meander.

6. Excursion with drift

We now present some results about the Brownian excursion with drift. We provide a construction which is analogous to that of the drifted Brownian meander. We consider the sequence of conditional processes {Bμ|Λu,v,c:u,c>v}conditional-setsuperscript𝐵𝜇:subscriptΛ𝑢𝑣𝑐𝑢𝑐𝑣\{B^{\mu}|\Lambda_{u,v,c}:u,c>v\} whose sample paths lie in sets of the form Λu,v,c={ω∈C​[0,T]:min0≤z≤t⁡ω​(z)>v,ω​(0)=u,ω​(t)=c}subscriptΛ𝑢𝑣𝑐conditional-set𝜔𝐶0𝑇formulae-sequencesubscript0𝑧𝑡𝜔𝑧𝑣formulae-sequence𝜔0𝑢𝜔𝑡𝑐\Lambda_{u,v,c}=\{\omega\in C[0,T]:{\min_{0\leq z\leq t}\omega(z)>v},\,\,\omega(0)=u,\,\,\omega(t)=c\}, with c,u>v𝑐𝑢𝑣c,u>v. We study the distribution of these processes and of process Bμ|Λv,v,vconditionalsuperscript𝐵𝜇subscriptΛ𝑣𝑣𝑣B^{\mu}|\Lambda_{v,v,v} defined as the weak limit of Bμ|Λu,v,cconditionalsuperscript𝐵𝜇subscriptΛ𝑢𝑣𝑐B^{\mu}|\Lambda_{u,v,c} when the starting point u𝑢u and the endpoint c𝑐c collapse onto the barrier v𝑣v.

Theorem 6.1.

thus the finite dimensional distributions of the excursion with drift coincide with the corresponding finite dimensional distributions of the driftless Brownian excursion. ∎

Remark 6.1.

We observe that in analogy with result (6.3) Beghin and Orsingher [1] showed that the distribution

P​{max0≤s≤t⁡Bμ​(s)>β|Bμ​(t)=η}=e−2​β​(β−η)t𝑃conditional-setsubscript0𝑠𝑡superscript𝐵𝜇𝑠𝛽superscript𝐵𝜇𝑡𝜂superscript𝑒2𝛽𝛽𝜂𝑡P\left\{\max_{0\leq s\leq t}B^{\mu}(s)>\beta\Big{|}B^{\mu}(t)=\eta\right\}=e^{-\frac{2\beta(\beta-\eta)}{t}}

is independent of μ𝜇\mu for every η𝜂\eta.

Weak convergence to the Brownian excursion has been established in [11].
